meanings.definition: Unwillingness to accept views, beliefs, or behavior that differ from one's own.
meanings.sent1: Her intolerance towards new ideas made it hard for her to make friends.
meanings.sent2: His intolerance of people with different opinions led to many arguments.
meanings.sent3: The intolerance of the cat towards the new puppy was quite comical.
meanings.sent4: The intolerance in the room was so thick, you could cut it with a knife.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's intolerance for cheating was well-known among the students.

meanings.definition: Inability to tolerate a particular substance or food.
meanings.sent1: His intolerance to dairy products meant he had to avoid ice cream.
meanings.sent2: The baby's intolerance to gluten made meal planning a challenge for the parents.
meanings.sent3: The intolerance of the computer to viruses was a relief for the user.
meanings.sent4: The intolerance of the car engine to low-quality fuel caused it to sputter.
meanings.sent5: The doctor diagnosed her intolerance to peanuts after a series of tests.

meanings.sent1: The teacher's intolerance for late assignments was well-known among the students.
meanings.sent2: His intolerance for waiting in line often led to frustration.
meanings.sent3: The intolerance of the toddler for long car rides made family trips challenging.
meanings.sent4: The intolerance of the clock for being ignored was evident in its loud ticking.
meanings.sent5: Her intolerance for noise made it difficult for her to concentrate on her work.
